name: HttpResponse
comment:
An HTTP response, which returns the headers and data from the server to the client in response to an HTTP request.

Every HttpRequest object provides access to the associated redstone/redstone_mocks.HttpResponse object through the response property. The server sends its response to the client by writing to the HttpResponse object.

Writing the response

This class implements redstone/redstone_mocks.IOSink. After the header has been set up, the methods from IOSink, such as writeln(), can be used to write the body of the HTTP response. Use the close() method to close the response and send it to the client.

server.listen((HttpRequest request) {
  request.response.write('Hello, world!');
  request.response.close();
});

When one of the IOSink methods is used for the first time, the request header is sent. Calling any methods that change the header after it is sent throws an exception.

Setting the headers

The HttpResponse object has a number of properties for setting up the HTTP headers of the response. When writing string data through the IOSink, the encoding used is determined from the "charset" parameter of the "Content-Type" header.

HttpResponse response = ...
response.headers.contentType
    = new ContentType("application", "json", charset: "utf-8");
response.write(...);  // Strings written will be UTF-8 encoded.

If no charset is provided the default of ISO-8859-1 (Latin 1) will be used.

HttpResponse response = ...
response.headers.add(HttpHeaders.CONTENT_TYPE, "text/plain");
response.write(...);  // Strings written will be ISO-8859-1 encoded.

An exception is thrown if you use the write() method while an unsupported content-type is set.

bufferOutput.name: bufferOutput
bufferOutput.comment:
Get or set if the redstone/redstone_mocks.HttpResponse should buffer output.

Default value is true.

Note: Disabling buffering of the output can result in very poor performance, when writing many small chunks.

contentLength.name: contentLength
contentLength.comment: Gets and sets the content length of the response. If the size of the response is not known in advance set the content length to -1 - which is also the default if not set.

deadline.name: deadline
deadline.comment:
Set and get the redstone/redstone_mocks.HttpResponse.deadline for the response. The deadline is timed from the time it's set. Setting a new deadline will override any previous deadline. When a deadline is exceeded, the response will be closed and any further data ignored.

To disable a deadline, set the redstone/redstone_mocks.HttpResponse.deadline to null.

The redstone/redstone_mocks.HttpResponse.deadline is null by default.

persistentConnection.name: persistentConnection
persistentConnection.comment: Gets and sets the persistent connection state. The initial value of this property is the persistent connection state from the request.

reasonPhrase.name: reasonPhrase
reasonPhrase.comment:
Gets and sets the reason phrase. If no reason phrase is explicitly set a default reason phrase is provided.

The reason phrase must be set before the body is written to. Setting the reason phrase after writing to the response body or closing the response will throw a StateError.

statusCode.name: statusCode
statusCode.comment:
Gets and sets the status code. Any integer value is accepted. For the official HTTP status codes use the fields from redstone/dart-io.HttpStatus. If no status code is explicitly set the default value redstone/dart-io.HttpStatus.OK is used.

The status code must be set before the body is written to. Setting the status code after writing to the response body or closing the response will throw a StateError.

encoding.name: encoding
encoding.comment: The redstone/dart-convert.Encoding used when writing strings. Depending on the underlying consumer this property might be mutable.

connectionInfo.name: connectionInfo
connectionInfo.comment: Gets information about the client connection. Returns null if the socket is not available.

cookies.name: cookies
cookies.comment: Cookies to set in the client (in the 'set-cookie' header).

headers.name: headers
headers.comment:
Returns the response headers.

The response headers can be modified until the response body is written to or closed. After that they become immutable.

detachSocket.name: detachSocket
detachSocket.comment:
Detaches the underlying socket from the HTTP server. When the socket is detached the HTTP server will no longer perform any operations on it.

This is normally used when a HTTP upgrade request is received and the communication should continue with a different protocol.

If redstone/redstone_mocks.HttpResponse.detachSocket.writeHeaders is true, the status line and redstone/redstone_mocks.HttpResponse.headers will be written to the socket before it's detached. If false, the socket is detached immediately, without any data written to the socket. Default is true.

redirect.name: redirect
redirect.comment:
Respond with a redirect to redstone/redstone_mocks.HttpResponse.redirect.location.

The URI in redstone/redstone_mocks.HttpResponse.redirect.location should be absolute, but there are no checks to enforce that.

By default the HTTP status code HttpStatus.MOVED_TEMPORARILY (302) is used for the redirect, but an alternative one can be specified using the redstone/redstone_mocks.HttpResponse.redirect.status argument.

This method will also call close, and the returned future is the furure returned by close.

done.name: done
done.comment: Get a future that will complete when the consumer closes, or when an error occurs. This future is identical to the future returned by redstone/redstone_mocks.HttpResponse.close.

hashCode.name: hashCode
hashCode.comment:
Get a hash code for this object.

All objects have hash codes. Hash codes are guaranteed to be the same for objects that are equal when compared using the equality operator ==. Other than that there are no guarantees about the hash codes. They will not be consistent between runs and there are no distribution guarantees.

If a subclass overrides redstone/redstone_mocks.HttpResponse.hashCode it should override the equality operator as well to maintain consistency.

runtimeType.name: runtimeType
runtimeType.comment: A representation of the runtime type of the object.

==.comment:
The equality operator.

The default behavior for all dart-core.Objects is to return true if and only if this and redstone/redstone_mocks.HttpResponse.==.other are the same object.

Override this method to specify a different equality relation on a class. The overriding method must still be an equivalence relation. That is, it must be:

  • Total: It must return a boolean for all arguments. It should never throw or return null.

  • Reflexive: For all objects o, o == o must be true.

  • Symmetric: For all objects o1 and o2, o1 == o2 and o2 == o1 must either both be true, or both be false.

  • Transitive: For all objects o1, o2, and o3, if o1 == o2 and o2 == o3 are true, then o1 == o3 must be true.

The method should also be consistent over time, so equality of two objects should not change over time, or at least only change if one of the objects was modified.

If a subclass overrides the equality operator it should override the redstone/redstone_mocks.HttpResponse.hashCode method as well to maintain consistency.

add.name: add
add.comment:
Adds redstone/redstone_mocks.HttpResponse.add.data to the target consumer, ignoring redstone/dart-io.IOSink.encoding.

The redstone/dart-io.IOSink.encoding does not apply to this method, and the data list is passed directly to the target consumer as a stream event.

This function must not be called when a stream is currently being added using redstone/redstone_mocks.HttpResponse.addStream.

This operation is non-blocking. See redstone/redstone_mocks.HttpResponse.flush or redstone/redstone_mocks.HttpResponse.done for how to get any errors generated by this call.

The data list should not be modified after it has been passed to add.

addError.name: addError
addError.comment:
Passes the error to the target consumer as an error event.

This function must not be called when a stream is currently being added using redstone/redstone_mocks.HttpResponse.addStream.

This operation is non-blocking. See redstone/redstone_mocks.HttpResponse.flush or redstone/redstone_mocks.HttpResponse.done for how to get any errors generated by this call.

addStream.name: addStream
addStream.comment: Adds all elements of the given redstone/redstone_mocks.HttpResponse.addStream.stream to this.

flush.name: flush
flush.comment:
Returns a redstone/dart-async.Future that completes once all buffered data is accepted by the to underlying redstone/redstone_mocks.StreamConsumer.

It's an error to call this method, while an redstone/redstone_mocks.HttpResponse.addStream is incomplete.

NOTE: This is not necessarily the same as the data being flushed by the operating system.

noSuchMethod.name: noSuchMethod
noSuchMethod.comment:
redstone/redstone_mocks.HttpResponse.noSuchMethod is invoked when users invoke a non-existent method on an object. The name of the method and the arguments of the invocation are passed to redstone/redstone_mocks.HttpResponse.noSuchMethod in an dart-core.Invocation. If redstone/redstone_mocks.HttpResponse.noSuchMethod returns a value, that value becomes the result of the original invocation.

The default behavior of redstone/redstone_mocks.HttpResponse.noSuchMethod is to throw a dart-core.NoSuchMethodError.

toString.name: toString
toString.comment: Returns a string representation of this object.

write.name: write
write.comment:
Converts redstone/redstone_mocks.HttpResponse.write.obj to a String by invoking redstone/redstone_mocks.HttpResponse.toString and redstone/redstone_mocks.HttpResponse.adds the encoding of the result to the target consumer.

This operation is non-blocking. See redstone/redstone_mocks.HttpResponse.flush or redstone/redstone_mocks.HttpResponse.done for how to get any errors generated by this call.

writeAll.name: writeAll
writeAll.comment:
Iterates over the given redstone/redstone_mocks.HttpResponse.writeAll.objects and redstone/redstone_mocks.HttpResponse.writes them in sequence.

If redstone/redstone_mocks.HttpResponse.writeAll.separator is provided, a write with the separator is performed between any two elements of objects.

This operation is non-blocking. See redstone/redstone_mocks.HttpResponse.flush or redstone/redstone_mocks.HttpResponse.done for how to get any errors generated by this call.

writeCharCode.name: writeCharCode
writeCharCode.comment:
Writes the redstone/redstone_mocks.HttpResponse.writeCharCode.charCode to this.

This method is equivalent to write(new String.fromCharCode(charCode)).

This operation is non-blocking. See redstone/redstone_mocks.HttpResponse.flush or redstone/redstone_mocks.HttpResponse.done for how to get any errors generated by this call.

writeln.name: writeln
writeln.comment:
Converts redstone/redstone_mocks.HttpResponse.writeln.obj to a String by invoking redstone/redstone_mocks.HttpResponse.toString and writes the result to this, followed by a newline.

This operation is non-blocking. See redstone/redstone_mocks.HttpResponse.flush or redstone/redstone_mocks.HttpResponse.done for how to get any errors generated by this call.
